title: Anet A8 Fan Shroud for Power Supply
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a cooling fan shroud for the Anet A8 power supply. It was designed to fit the 20 Amp version, which is 110mm wide and 50mm thick. This shroud provides two air flow paths, through the case as well as over the top panel which the power supply uses as a heat sink. The fan should be oriented so it pulls air in through the power supply blows out and away from it. This shroud accomodates a 50mm box fan.

Added a second version that fits an 80mm fan. This one is untested, so please give feedback if you print it.

comments.text: How would you go about wiring the fan since there are not connecters left on the main board
comments.author: Hammy3DPrints

comments.text: It's wired directly to the terminals on the power supply, there's no need to connect it to the main board.
comments.author: Hammy3DPrints

comments.text: Thank you Freemark. I'm happy to report the 80mm version prints and works well. I own a 2017 model, for reference.

comments.text: Actually it is for a 50mm fan. Contrary to popular belief, the correct size measurement is the width of the whole fan, not the distance between screw holes. Nice remix though.

comments.text: Thanks, but fan measuraments is taken (usually) is the distance between screw holes.
comments.author: freemark

comments.text: People often believe that, but it's not correct. Fan size vs hole distance is referenced here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_fan#Physical_characteristics. Also, you can google for fan spec sheets.

comments.author: freemark

comments.text: In this design the fan is supposed to be mounted on the outside as shown in the photos, with the fan blowing away from the power supply, so it will accomodate your fans as is. The internal space behind the fan is a plenum to improve air flow and is not intended to house the fan. I have also designed some fan grilles if you're interested: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1879694
comments.author: CharlieB49

comments.text: I printed one, for the most part it fits well. The fan frame clicked right in on the inside, just the slight misalignment of the mounting holes. Also, think that if the fan would mount on the inside of the frame and incorporating a fan grill for safety of someones fingers, but that would take a slightly more material to print. Also,  I think that adding a lip that wraps around the right side and extend the top one all the way across or just to the right side would make more mounting points. Will snap a pic and draw what I mean if you want.
comments.author: freemark

comments.text: Ok, thanks for the feedback. I like the lip idea, it should allow it to mount a little more securely. The opening in the back is intentional, in order to provide more air flow over the top plate, which the power supply uses as a heat sink. The 80mm version is a requested design mod that I did not actually print. How far off are the mounting holes? Can you give me a center to center measurement? I also like the idea of having a grill, and think maybe I'll design one as a separate piece that can be used optionally.
comments.author: Cepega_3D

comments.text: I used those big screws that are intended specifically for the cooling cans. The holes were maybe about 1mil or so off, but the screws went right in and held in place pretty well, so I guess should not be too much of a consern. I only used two screws diagonally from each other to mount it and the other 2 screws were mounted usin the other diagonal position to hold the grill in place.
comments.author: freemark

comments.text: Hmmm, I measured 71mm center to center on a fan I had, but I thought the dimension was odd since on my 50 & 60mm fans the hole spacing measured exactly 10mm less than the outer dimensions. Maybe I'll redo a version with the holes elongated diagonally by a couple of mm. Thanks for the info.

title: ToM Y axis idler belt pulley shaft double shear stiffener

description.text:
It takes the ToM Y axis idler belt pulley shaft and puts it in double shear making it stiffer and keeps the belt tension more consistant.
It also takes the stress off the clear plastic.

I made mine with 15% fill and it's OK.
The holes should take the screws without tapping or needing those nuts that I always drop. I also added the Autodesk 123D file in case you need to make changes.

description.text: AC Knob for carrier wall unit ac

This is a caster with 1" diameter wheel.
You could add a 3D printed axle, though that's not currently included.
The -002 rev of the wheel holder has thicker walls.

The mounting holes are for M3 screws. The axle hole is about .215 diameter when printed, so I'm using a 10-32 x 1 screw and nut as the axle. This could be scaled for a larger caster!

The original files were done in Solidworks and moved into Onshape. Want to modify it more? It's a public doc! Check it out here!
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/7ccf42f439624c3432bf742d/w/e5510a5a74e7121f8ee97933/e/7d7f52a4ee0212af2d4d42ac

If you go into this document, you'll see the mount has some weird features with the mounting hole pattern. I had some Solidworks version compatibility issues across my different computers, and filing the holes in Onshape didn't print as cleanly as I'd like. When I get a hold of the original file, I'll change the hole pattern and re-upload the file in Onshape.

Printer:

FF Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Extruder temp: 205C
Bed temp: 35C
Bed surface: smooth ABS sheet, mounted to bed with double stick tape

title: OpenForge 2.0 Trap Door Construction Kit Parts

description.text:
These are trap door floor parts for use in the OpenForge 2.0 Wall Construction Kit. Go there to understand how these are to be used.

I strongly recommend printing the trapdoor with the upright file, as you get way better detail on the wood grain if it's printed on the z axis.

If new trap door floor sizes get made in the future, I'll update this thing with the appropriate pieces.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

Assembly

Underneath the floor tile, there is a divot for holding the hinge. Straighten and cut a paperclip to fit that divot and then slide it into the hole on the side of the trapdoor. Depending on how well your printer does with bridging, you may need to use an xacto to clean up the divot and a drill or pin vice to clean out the hole in the trap door. Place the trapdoor in place in the floor tile, with the hinge running through it. Place any magnets you want to use in the base. Use cyanoacrylate glue (superglue) to glue the floor to the base, trapping the hinge. Note: the metal hinge will draw the magnets, so you want to slap the floor onto the base pretty fast or it can create a little bit of a mess.

Changelog
  • 8/19/16 - Added corner construction kit floors

comments.text: Careful there! Remember to model some posts and warning tape or you'll be responsible if some ijit leaves this open and someone's miniature falls into it!  :-))
comments.author: mmorao

author: devonjones

description.text:
The working trapdoor here is in two styles, cut-stone and wood. These must be done in the OpenForge 2.0 style to make the trap door functional, so there's no full_base option (ping me if what you want is just a non working trapdoor for the 1.0.)

I strongly recommend printing the trapdoor using the trapdoor_upright file, as you get way better detail if the wood grain is on the z axis.

Parts for building this next to a wall are in their own thing for the wall construction kit.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

title: Music Drop (Fixed Bits & Game Of Thrones Edition)

description.text:
I've been working on this print for a couple weeks now. I can understand why there are no posted makes as I'm sure the success rate is almost nil. I repaired several of the models in Meshmixer and sharing. I'm also including the dragon egg version of the case. I had a gift idea recessing the drop inside a dragon egg and have it play a tidbit of the Game of Thrones intro. (disc included since the music drop site is apparently offline now)

The result looks cool but I can't really make out the tune. Even at a very fine tip I couldn't get the original disc to come out very well so I recreated the notes inside Tinkercad with little bit better posts; unfortunately, I can only barely make out the tune.

To strengthen the trigger posts and disc, I used a brush on super glue on the surface of which seems to work very well and keeps the trigger posts from breaking (which happened to me on the original design even with glue).

The instructions say to put the screws in from behind but for some reason the nuts dampened the tines. I also had to use a washer for a spacer instead of nuts since mine apparently are bigger (uhhh... that didn't sound right). LOL

I hope they bring the site back online as I would like to finish my other one with a different tune. Might be a reason to play with OpenSCAD.

UPDATE

The site appears to be back up: http://musicdrop.leftfieldlabs.com/

UPDATE 2

Spoke too soon, site is back down or just having issues. LOL

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.10mm

Infill:

80%

Notes:

I used -5mm on the Z-axis when positioning on the bed to give it a flat bottom to stand upright on its own.

Very intricate and I ended up printing with a 0.25mm nozzle. The egg case I printed with .40mm nozzle at 20% infill, but I did print an original case with the above settings (unfinished currently). I used green and yellow eSun PETG.

To give you an idea of the repairs. The case was error ridden and Simplify3D just wouldn't slice it right causing missing pieces and weird lines missing. The little fixer cap was literally turned inside out, so I had to flip normals to make it properly solid.

Ummm... no wonder why S3D laughed when I tried to slice it. Looks Sooooo much cleaner after nearly spending an entire day repairing it manually in Meshmixer.

comments.text:
great thinking, and awesome work.
there are several lines of the tune missing though - sry Pianist alert.

comments.text: Just a few, for sure. I had more crammed on it and you couldn't make it out, at all! lol

title: Dial Indicator bracket suite
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I needed some brackets to hold a dial indicator in place for measuring the travel distance for all three axes on my Prusa. And I didn't want to have to remove the extruder or anything like that. This simple set of parts should solve that problem for all of us. This set may work on Mendel and other similar builds.

The openscad model is mostly parametric - there are still some hard values in there and I was tired of messing around and decided to release it as-is. Use bracketYZ for measuring both Y and Z movement. bracketX for the X dimension. I use 6-32 nuts and bolts for securing both the indicator as well as the bar clamp. I found that a wingnut actually works better and allows you to get more clamping force on the bar than the captured nut does... ymmv Get cracking and get your steps/mm accurately calibrated! Notes: This is also useful for measuring backlash. To eliminate any effect of backlash on your initial reading make sure to make one movement after a direction change before zeroing your indicator. Ex: make a back movement, then a forward movement. Zero indicator, and measure the next forward movement. To measure backlash: make a forward movement, set the indicator to zero, then make a backward movement, you'll see the difference if you've already dialed in a non-backlash-inducing movement.

Since the Flexion extruder has a slightly different hotend, it came too close to the plastic on the original version, which eventually started to melt. This version adds a bit more clearance around the hotend, and should fix that problem.

If you don't use a Flexion extruder on your Replicator, do not use this version. Instead, use Prot0typ1cal's Replicator 2 Duct. You can also go there to find out how to install this fan duct:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1650941

Please also note that this version of the top covers is more challenging to print than the original ones, so if you have doubts, then use the original version.

description.text:
I ve made this for the Opto Endstops shipped with my Prusa Mendel Kit. These tiny Endstop PCBs have SMD light barriers and only one hole to fix. So i planed in a slot to prevent the PCB from rotating. Todo:
  • a wheel for the adjusting screw.
  • maybe print the opto bar in an other direction, because the slot for the square nut gets filled while printing horizontal.

There is a bit of mechanical work after printing out. Tools needed:
Drills 3mm, 2,5mm
Drill press (if available)
Thread cutter M3 Screws:
3x M3 x 40
2x M3 x 25
2x M3 Square Nuts (mine have 5,5x5,5 mm edges)
M3 washers and nuts one smalll spring Build it: finish the two small holes in the clamp bar with a 2,5mm drill. The hole in the middle with 3mm. Cut 3mm threads in the 2,5mm holes.
Drill the three holes of the opto bar with 3mm if needed. The screws have to move light.
Put two m3x40 screws through the outer holes of the opto bar into the clamps threads until they come out on the other side for ~3mm. Lock the screws ends with a nut.
Put a square nut in the opto bar and a spring between clamp and opto bar. Now put the last M3x40 screw from the side of the nuts (locking the other screws) through the spring into the square nut of the opto bar.
Fix the pcb on the bar with a screw an a nut.
Mount the unit with the clamp and another square nut and screw. You can decide, depending of your needs, how to place the opto bar on top or downside the clamp. Keep in mind, that the adjusting screw has to point on the top for easy adjusting. Adjust and feel fine ;)

My daughter wanted to be a musketeer for Halloween so I made this handle based off of rapiers I saw online.  I have uploaded both the complete handle as well as the left and right split.

I have an oversize bed, so if you have smaller than 240x300 bed you will have to scale. It ended up being too large for my daughters hand so I printed it at 80%. I think even at 80% it is plenty big as it almost fits my hand as well, and I have very large hands. I split the handle into two pieces and then glued the halves together. I printed mine with support material, and it came out better than I thought. If I had one thing I would change, it would be the support material alignment. Because of how my program (repetier) created the support, one half of it broke off during the print and I had to glue it back midprint. After I paint it, I'll upload photos of the finished product.

description.text:
This is a wall hanger for the boxes of black gloves that Harbor Freight sells.

This is optimized for 3D printing but the wall thickness is 3mm (.118 inches) to allow laser or CNC cutting from standard materials like acrylic. The cost is likely about the same for either 3d print or laser cutting but the tradeoff is time. This is loosely an 8 hour 3D print or a 8 minute laser cut (with CNC somewhere between); depending on your exact machine specifications. I am 3D printing one solely to verify that my printer hot ends upgrades are working reliably over time, for example.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aXR0sfMJxHx

title: Trojan 3D Geared Extruder 1.75mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Trojan 3D Extruder is made for high performance and long hassle free life!!
Compatible with i3 and typical 23x23mm x-carriage hole patterns.
Very small footprint.
Nema 14 Motor with fully printed 0.6 module gears but ZERO backlash!!
Only 310 gr. fully assembled!! Less than a nema17 motor alone.
An easy simple idler with no springs
ED3 V6 or VOLCANO pack compatible
Integrated fans for a better cooling and no jam in all conditions
Integrated JST micro plug for a quick fan removal if service is required.
All the supports already integrated in the design, just remove it easily after print
2 parts main body for a very easy print and service
Water Cooled hotend version coming soon!!

Printer:

Custom 3D Printer

Resolution:

0.2mm Layer

Infill:

See "Infill settings"

Notes:

Printed with 0.4 nozzle,
0.2 mm Layer

There's a lot of extruders around, TOO BIG AND HEAVY!!!.
So i decided to make a smaller one..........
That's all.

https://youtu.be/OtJU2YnWw0o

REMINDER!!!!!!!

IF your printer is NOT well calibrated and NOT accurate you will not be able to print successfully the TROJAN EXTRUDER.
The files and the project tolerances are based on my printer which is very accurate, so please be sure to print the Spur Gears first, the bearings should be able to fit with a small pressure(NOT WITH A HAMMER!!).
I will be happy to change the tolerance if required, but i cannot make all happy :-))

ºHotend Clamp 100% Infill - 0.2 layers - 2 Perimeters
ºSpur Gears 100% Infill - 0.2 layers - 2 Perimeters
ºIdler 100% Infill - 0.2 layers - 2 Perimeters (Please rotate the Idler DX part as for the outside on the printing plane)
ºHotend Blower-1 100% Infill - 0.2 layers - 2 Perimeters
ºHotend Blower-2 55% Infill - 0.2 layers - 2 Perimeters (gently remove the side support and the rings parts inside after printing)
ºCarter-4mm-Axe/5mm Axe 100% Infill - 0.2 Layers - 2 Perimeters
ºRetainer Ring 100% Infill - 0.2 Layers - 3 Perimeters
ºHeat-Sink_Cooler 40% Infill - 0.2 Layers - 2 Perimeters (gently remove the support rings by pushing from the back side)
ºIdler-Pin 100% Infill - 0.2 Layers - 2 Perimeters
ºBodyPart-1 & 2 100%Infill - 0.2 Layers - 2Perimeters

List of materials and Links

1)For the "Spur Gear 40-26" you will need: 2 x 684 2rs- (4x9x4mm) radial bearings, remove the support ring.
2)For the idler you will need: 1x 625 2rs-(5x16x5mm) radial bearing plus
I found very useful use the POZY PAN SELF TAPPING SCREWS 2.9x19mm
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/361393954180 easy and fast

3)For the hobbed pulley shaft you will need: 2x 625 2rs-(5x16x5mm) radial bearing
4)One piece 16T 5mm bore 0.6 metric module pinion http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/331445033964
4)One piece 5x46mm precision shaft, (hobbed pulley drive)
6)One piece 4x21mm precision shaft (intermediate spur gear 40/26-T)
7Just ask for the lenght you need to the seller by leaving a message http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/271328896010
8)Link for the hobbed pulley drive (very high quality) http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/221487842821
9)1xNema14 stepper motor 20oz torque, I'm using this one, is not bad http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/121577096859
10)One 30x10mm fan 12V (heatsink)
11)One 35 or 40x10mm fan 12V (hot-end side) at your choice as both files are provided
12)2x micro-jst plugs for the fans http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/171967381367
13)9x M3x4mm Threaded Round Metal Knurl Thread Insert Nuts Brass for the BodyPart-1 & 2 And the Idler

1) The Idler is in 2 parts, after printing just clean the pins and make them fit the small holes for the alignement, then glue with super glue or normal UHU pla glue, they fit perfectly.
Then add the brass knurl nut in the side hole, add some super glue to ensure that will stay in place for a very long time, i used for mine and is very hard to remove after, just be carefull to screw in a bolt in the thread so the glue will not affect the funcionality.

2) For the Hot-End Blower2 fan, you have to remove the original external case of the fan (Will post illustrated instructions soon), soldering the new plug wire to the motor, then glue with superglue the motor to the plastic case.
Is an easy job as inside the plastic case i already provided the centering ring and bore, so you have just accomodate the motor in place and make sure is really in place... just make sure to clean all the old supporting arms from the motor.
3) Same apply to the Heat-Sink_cooler fan support, remove the external case from the 30mm fan and follow the same procedure as the Hot-End Blower
4) The BodyPart need to be completed by adding the brass nuts, if you find some hole a bit too easy to fit just add some super glue, will work great.I can't match all of your printers tolerance, this is just for mine.
DO NOT PRINT THEM AT HIGH SPEED, YOU WILL GET JUST A BAD JOB!!!!
As you can see from the uploaded pictures they come out very clean and neat, so is up to you to repeat the same job.

Custom parts on demand

Please note:
1)I added the 40/26T Spur Gear MR105.STL file, it fit the MR105 radial bearing which is 4x10x5mm bore.
for now is only the spur gear, soon i will add the other files to make this gear work with the TROJAN.

2)Added the Hotend Blower2 40mm.stl (for the 40mm diameter fan) as requested.
3)Added the 5mm shaft Gear-cover Carter-5mm-Axe.stl file

comments.text:
The reason of the 35mm fan is because due to the aerodinamics of the ducts the flow is equal to a 40mm fan (read carefully!!)
The 90% of the 40mm cooler ducts are made without any simulation or aerodinamics knowledge,(without any offence to the designer which always do a great job to help the community by sharing their designs, we share for fun, not for a profit).
All the computer fans are made to work in open air, every other attempt to transport the airflow thru a restricted duct result in a compression, and that generate just turbulence in the inlet side of the airflow(turbulence mean a drastic drop of the flow).
So using a 40mm fan with a small outlet bore due to the wrong air path is perfectly useless.
Those type of fans are not designed to generate ANY pressure, so the result is a poor airflow in all conditions if they are restricted .
Personally i use just high speed fan with ball bearings and different blade shape, for me they are the best (http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/391295510207 for example)
With this design i kept the flow open and the airpath doesen't generate any pressure, so a maximum flow even with a 35mm fan, which allow me to design a smaller and lighter piece with the same airflow as a 40mm fan at the end of the game.
I already have more than 300 hours printing with my extruder without any sort of problem, no jamming and a good cooling on the surface.
As stated at the beginning this is not designed for high speed and poor quality, and i am more than happy with what i have on my printers, all the pieces are printed with the TROJAN, i can print a 2mm diameter pin without any problem and perfectly round, so really i'm not searching fore more.
Hope that this boring conference of mine can make some clarity.
And please let me know how is going with the parts, some pictures will be very helpful :-)
Regards
comments.author: thed0ct0r

comments.text:
not boring at all, in fact, i really appreciate your willingness to discuss and explain the reasoning behind your decisions as a designer.
i hope you do not find my questions and suggestions to be offensive or to say that you did something wrong.

comments.text:
I can easily remove all the support in all my parts, that's why i asked to print the gear first.
For the MR105 gear just put a small flat screw driver into the ring and force a bit, it will detach easily
I use just a small screw driver, and with a very little pressure they just come up with no damage to the structure, if you had to adgjust the bore of the bearings then you may consider to create a separate config file to your slicer and reduce a bit the extruder flow, this will give you more space between the support and the part.
I can assure you, i do not have any problem to remove the rings or other support parts, most of the time they remain sticked to the glass when i remove the printed part. the gap is 0.2mm between the part and all the supports(basically a layer), if i incerease the gap the pla will not be printed properly on top of the support and i will not have a good underneath surface as i have now.
If you succesfully removed the hot-end clamp ring then the same should happen to the other parts
Please try to reduce the extruder flow a bit and let me know
Thanks a lot
comments.author: thed0ct0r

comments.text:
i've managed to remove all of the supports using an mdf screw (i screw it in the supports and pull), some of them were very hard to remove even then. i think it mainly depends on the brand of filament you use, even PLA has a lot of variation between mfg's.
i actually have much more experience printing petg than pla, and i can tell right away that removing some of these in petg will be next to impossible (petg has an extremely strong layer to layer bonding, so rafts are mostly impossible for example, and supports have to be very precise, which is why i'm first printing this in PLA).
i could not remove the supports from the idler_sx (well half was removed easily, the other half has bonded to strongly i guess), i might have to reprint that with a lower extrusion, but this was already printed at a lower extrusion than optimal, and i think it will show signs of under extrusion if i lower even more. i will let you know how it goes...

comments.text:
Hi,
Thank you for the comments, i'm updating the info as fast as possible, (sadly i have to work in the meantime)
I'm up to release the files at the end of August for sure, just adjusting and testing the main body as i modified the file.
The gear ratio is 1/3.88 using the 17T(as i use) for the motor pinion 0.6 metric module, it give you enough torque leaving the extruder fast in retraction.
The hobbed pulley is 10.1mm diameter and with the one i use you really need just to gently push the filament with the idler, it works great.
This is not a super fast extruder, the nema 14 stepper has his limit sadly, but i can print at 70/80mm-sec with no problem.
I cannot see the point in achieving high speed, the goal was to design a precise extruder for quality printing parts, speed and quality doesen't match in a 3D printer for my experience, is a phisical limit of the material due to the printing system.
At today all my printers are using the Trojan, and i already have more than 250 hours without any problem or service required.
i will post a video, so you can have an idea before start printing.....
I'm not experiencing the heating problem as you quote the Toranado Extruder, but is my personal setup, the Toranado is a great extruder, and Wes (the designer) has made a very wonderful work!
I will list all the parts you need for assembly the TROJAN, and if i miss something just let me know.
Any question feel free to ask :-)
All the best.

Even Wes with the TORANADO changed the design from circular to the back of the extruder body as it wasn't goog for him.
The 360 degree circular fan duct is just a choice, but personally i don't like it as the front/rear cooling system works well for me, and i'd been printing for a while now, so i will not design a circular one, sorry.
Another thing about the support or printing in mid air, i am a fan of the support material, and my goal is to create a printer with the double indipendent extruder and dedicate one of them to print water soluble support material as i do not believe that the mid air printed parts are accurate.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed without support, but had some droops on Pot.stl and part of Arm.stl. They do not affect functionality and are in a concealed position, but I'll print with support if I were to go again. If you plan to add a growlight, do not auto-add support for Arm.stl as it may block the cable passage!

description.text:
The cloud "rains" down on the plant when watering. A reservoir at the bottom collects excess water and keeps the soil moist when you're away. A hidden slot in the arm allows for the mounting of an optional LED grow light.

Inspired by the Wall Flower Mount (Click) by 3DPVDB.

Optional:
I'm using this LED from eBay. It's supposed to be for 15V, but I'm running it just fine with a 12V power supply. I bought my power supply off a local shop, but any cheap power supply capable of supplying at least 500mA should do fine. Most plants would do just fine with 24hrs of light, but add a timer if you want to give your plants some rest.

Printer:

RigidBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The cloud and arm are printed with normal PLA, while the main body and pot are printed with FormFutura EasyWood (Birch).

I printed without support, but had some droops on Pot.stl and part of Arm.stl. They do not affect functionality and are in a concealed position, but I'll print with support if I were to go again. If you plan to add a growlight, do not auto-add support for Arm.stl as it may block the cable passage!

The parts are waterproof as printed with no special effort (tested). But I also painted the interior of the reservoir with a two part epoxy as an additional layer of protection. It's not strictly necessary, and there are many other ways to do it.

The cloud was painted over with white acrylic paint, as my white PLA has an ivory hue, and I didn't want to buy another roll of filament just for this print.

title: Parkour dude jumping over brick wall

description.text:
made during a internship with the crazy Thomas Parkour dude! enjoy & remix :)
the Parkour dude is a vectorized raster image (used Inkscape) => DXF => SWX => 3d part scaled & plug connection to brick wall
the text was just scaled and fused in an angle with SWX to the brick wall

printed successful with:
PETG silver (200-230°C extruder, 90°C bed recommended)
settings used:
40% infill
210°C extruder
75°C bed (90°C part removing was almost not possible, 60°C to much warping)
~50°C cabinet

10-40% is by far enough, for wall part with text three outside layers recommended for better text quality. Text angle ~47° => no support needed on most printers.

The rectangular plug connection needs some sanding in the end to fit nice, we used a small file to do this.

cheers,
Martin & Thomas

Printer:

Cubicon Single 110F

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 Layer; 0,4 Nozzle

Infill:

20-40%

title: video transmitter fixation bracket for IRIS plus

description.text:
FPV transmitter can become really HOT, and generally the bond/tape cannot stand it well...Then if it fall you may have a bad day.
So I made this very light fixation bracket to keep it steadily in place.

put the transmitter inside secured it with some 2 faces tape (optional, it should work well even without tape), and just clip it under a leg of your IRIS plus, then fly!

PRINT IT IN ABS, NO PLA!!

PS: I put a 0.5mm thick aluminium sheet to act as a heat dissipator on mine, but the tx is a regular BOSCAM 600mW, nothing odd.

EDIT 2016/07/31
I made a 2nd version, just added a bit more thickness on the bottom part and on the clamps to get a better grip.

title: Side-Mounted Spool Holder for Lulzbot Mini

description.text:
This is a remix of the original Spool Mount / Holder designed by Aleph Objects for the Lulzbot Mini 3D Printer. The original had two problems, and a third minor inconvenience. This redesign allows for easy placement of a filament spool to the side of the printer and placement of the printer under a shelf.

The first is that the Spool Arm / Spool Holder was unable to be printed on the 6" x 6" print bed on a mini itself and instead had to printed on a larger printer like a TAZ. The second was that the Spool Mount went straight up above the printer and made it so the printer could not be placed on or under a low height shelf easily (the filament spool was unable to be placed on the side of the printer). The third minor inconvenience was that the Spool Arm for the Spool Holder was not rounded on the top and provided extra friction to a moving filament spool that should not have been there.

This remix / redesign of the original filament spool holder for the lulzbot mini aims at being a comprehensive replacement and fix for all of the issues mentioned above. Enjoy. :)

Special Print instructions:
1. In Cura place the mini spool mount diagonally to fit on the print bed. Cura will still show the item in grey as it seems to be too big for the print area.
2. Go to >Expert >Switch to full settings
3.Then go to >Expert >Open Expert Settings (Ctrl + E)
4.Under the SKIRT heading change "start distance (mm)" from 3mm to 1.9mm or 1.5mm. This should show the item in green and able to print now.
5.When the first Spool Mount side is printed one must click on the object in Cura and select the "Mirror Z" option. Then flip and re-align diagonally to print the mirrored second side and repeat steps 1 through 4 if needed.

Items needed for Spool Brace / Guide:
4 metric M5 brass inserts 94180A361.
can be obtained here
or here
and 4 M5 metric bolts (two may have come with your mini).

Source Files:
Spool_mount_camellia_v1.2.SLDPRT
Spool_arm_camellia.SLDPRT

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

No

No

40%

2. Go to >Expert >Switch to full settings
3.Then go to >Expert >Open Expert Settings (Ctrl + E)
4.Under the SKIRT heading change "start distance (mm)" from 3mm to 1.9mm or 1.5mm. This should show the item in green and able to print now.
5.When the first Spool Mount side is printed one must click on the object in Cura and select the "Mirror Z" option. Then flip and re-align diagonally to print the mirrored second side and repeat steps 1 through 4 if needed.

comments.text: Where do the heat set nuts get placed?  Looking at your assembly pictures.  I assume they get put into the arms and then the M5 bolts go thru the brace into the heat set nuts.  Since their are not holes in the assembly to put them right thru?
comments.author: calabris

comments.text: Yes, there should be a total of two heat sets per arm. They only go as deep as the holes allow and the bolts are not very long. I think the same as the ones holding the z-axis black drylin nuts. Though that's not to say this design could not be modified or other methods invented. Honestly you don't even need the brace or the inserts really as the arms should stay in place through friction.
comments.author: calabris

This is a new construction style I developed to help me print large boxes and walls without warping. These big boxes should print with no warping. Big box is 190mm wide 127mm deep and 100 mm tall. Larger box is 210mmx160mmx100mm. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:209056 for an organizer.

Printed on a Makergear M2 printer using ABS with the build platform at 95c using hair spray. I've tested with .35, .40 and .50mm nozzles and they all worked great. I usually print with ABS at 220c.  
If you have had problems printing large box like shapes please try to print this thing and let me know how it works for you.  
This construction style should eliminate ABS warping on big panels.

comments.text: I made the big box and my faith in ABS is restored. I've suffered through constant warping and delamination when printing large objects with ABS. This print came out great. I'll modify my future designs to take in some of the design features of this box.  Thanks for sharing Theo.

title: x-axis min/max endstop for microswitch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Another one...
Because of the thin X-carriage I use, (see https://www.thingiverse.com/make:215008, a make of the "Prusa i3 Rework X-carriage with additional holes for Wade's extruder" by AndrewBCN) I wanted the microswitch a little closer to the belt than I saw with the other designs.

And although I enjoyed designing the x-axis endstop for Prusa i3 Hesine, see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1515471, I now prefer using a couple of these.
More freedom in adjusting and also usable as max endstop.

Fit for 8mm sliding rods on a 45mm distance.

And: watch how you mount your screws, because of the closeness to the belt.

author: bathrobotics

description.text: This is a replica design of a gamepad of an 8 bits nintendo console, it is full working, not ornament, inside there is a board with the buttons and a board of an usb keyboard, if you want to see more, take a look: http://www.penpenblog.com/printed-3d-gamepad-nes-full-working This is my tribute to the 80s.

I made it with a 0,35mm hotend, with 0,25mm layer for the body and the top, and 0,15mm layer for the buttons, to get a better finish. I particularly use abs, but i guess there is no problem in use pla. I take a broken usb keyboard to get the controller board, solder the buttons to the appropriate pins to get working the keys i want. Then when i plug it to my pc, and i set these keys in the emulation software, to play with. I print the sticker on transparent sticker, because it is more durable than paper sticker.

description.text:
My first design. A stripper clip for a K31 7.5X55 Swiss rifle. For fast loading rounds into the top of the rifle.

The rounds stay in the clip if it is not shaken too much. There is also a clip to go on the bottom of the clip for transportation.

There are two versions. The standard 6 round one and a 5 round. The 5 round version I made for competitions which use, for example, 10 rounds. Not many use multiples of 6.

author: libraryinformatics

title: Another variation of the compact extruder for J-head

description.text:
After using for several days my previous version (and maybe due to vibration of the cooling fan) the hotend lost its alignment and filament feed increased drag quite a lot. I created this new version so that could not happen anymore.  
Hotend is fixed by two small pieces of 1.75mm filament sliding inside the holes (M3 screws won't fit)

comments.text:
Hola Miguel, me gusta el modelo de la Extrusora muchisimo..
He tenido algun problemilla muy sencillo de solucionar en el diseño y es que el alambre que sujeta la cabeza extrusora, por el movimiento y el calor termina dilatándose y saliendo del cabezal.. (Sobre todo con impresiones grandes..)
Te queria sugerir si me lo permites que el alambre salga de la extrusora por el otro lado para poder ponerle unos topes y evitar que se salga.
Por otro lado el dentado pequeño del motor del cabezal termina con holgura y al final patina en el eje del motor.
La idea que tuviste en el dentado grande de poner una cabeza exagonal tambien se la pondria al dentado pequeño para evitar que patinara.
Muchas gracias por los modelos y por el curso que me diste.

Ever had the idea of custom designing a cabinet door in a few easy steps? Well no need since we at Trotec have done so, and you can too. We've provided all the files for you to create your own inlaid acrylic cabinet door.

Step 1: Add masking tape

This mask prevents any staining or burning while laser cutting.

Step 1: Add masking tape Step 1: Add masking tape Step 1: Add masking tape Step 1: Add masking tape Step 2: Focus the laser

Focus the laser in the middle of the cabinet, doing so will make the cut very consistent. If we don't it could go out of focus. Program the Z-depth by measuring the distance from the top to middle. It will then focus automatically to the middle.

Step 2: Focus the laser Step 2: Focus the laser Step 3: Cut the wood

We laser cut the wood which is about 1/4" thick on a 80w Trotec Speedy 400 at 100 power and 0.3 Speed, and our Z-offset is -0.125 (for focusing into the middle).

Step 3: Cut the wood Step 4: Cut the acrylic

Increase the size of the acrylic by 0.05 inches. This was the kerf of the laser beam that cut the wooden door. CorelDraw do this using the outline contour tool.

Step 4: Cut the acrylic Step 4: Cut the acrylic Step 5: Do the inlay

Snap the acrylic in (if it's loose use krazy glue or acrylic glue).

ta daa! You now how a perfect acrylic inlaid sign, Enjoy!

Step 5: Do the inlay Step 5: Do the inlay Step 5: Do the inlay Step 5: Do the inlay

author: lunarwhirlwind

description.text:
The Sphere-O-bot is an open source hardware+software project. Originally from Evil Mad Scientist (very cool robots), we have adapted the idea to our electronics and ancillary elements. Software, designs and use is exactly the same.
The frame was designed by Attila Nagy (Thingiverse nick: dibloff)

The list of parts to print:
1x Spring holder
1x MAIN_frame (with support)
1x Egg support
1x Pen holder
2x Axis support
1x vertical ARM
1x Rod spacer
NEW!:1x M3 nut Knot (replacement for the metal wingnut). You do not really need the wingnut anymore
................................................................................

The Electronics are OPEN SOURCE (feel free to replicate it if you want)

You can also buy everything (customizable KIT): here
or create all the jjRobots with the MOST AWESOME ROBOTICS KIT

How to set it up?

Take a look at this link: http://jjrobots.com/sphere-o-bot-assembly-and-user-guide/

NEW!:
Sphere-o-bot KIT unpacking and alternative setting up video (thanks Geeksmithing!): here Sphere-o-bot Video on youtube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UrGMX7NNNxc

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

30

Notes:

PLA works nicely.

New!

Using the same electronics and motors you can create the B-robot EVO 2! the fastest and more stable self-balancing robot

What you need to create this painting robot

2x 623 bearing
1x Threaded steel rod (3mmØ,80mm length)
1x compression spring (4,5mmØ, 10 mm length)
2x 1.8deg HIGH QUALITY NEMA 17 Stepper motors (40mm length) (4.4Kg/cm torque)
Motor cables (14+70 cms long)
1x SG90 servo
1x Arduino Leonardo compatible
1x jjRobots Brain Shield
2x A4988 Stepper motor drivers
1x Power supply 12v/2A
6mm M3 bolts
12mm M3 bolts
M3 nuts
2x 20mm Suction Cups
1x M3 wing nut

OTHERS:

cable wrap (optional but makes everything look prettier..)

You can also buy the Sphere-O-Bot robot KIT (motors, electronics and ancillary elements) here: http://jjrobots.com/product/sphere-o-bot/

Sphere-o-bot KIT unpacking video

And alternative setting up guide (thanks Geeksmithing!)

Iboardbot, B-robot EVO...all the JJrobots

If you have created a B-robot EVO or the iBoardbot, you already have the electronics and almost all the ancillary elements needed to create your Sphere-O-bot! (yes, we have used the same items to create this drawing bot).
Take a look at the B-robot EVO, the iBoardbot and...THE MOST AWESOME ROBOTICS KIT

If you like the Sphere-o-bot and have a 3D printer, take a look at the MOST AWESOME ROBOTICs KIT

A kit of very different robots created from the same electronics and motors. Just print the frames and have fun! (and learn robotics with the Robotics Challenges with the Academy)
http://www.jjrobots.com/the-academy/

the MOST AWESOME ROBOTICs KIT

comments.text: Having a hard time getting the main frame to print on my monoprice IIp or my Folgertech 2020... both get about an hour in and then jumps in the Y direction...  Anyone else have this issue with the stl File?  Using Cura 2.3.1 with the settings in the details..  the layers look good in the layer view... getting frustrated and tired of wasting filament, I have tried multiple times on each machine and have the same issue with a shift in the Y
comments.author: cathyfc

comments.text:
Yes, I use an Arduino UNO R3
on my iMac, if I make many tries to connect, 1 time on 30, I arrive to connect with Inkscape
So, I think there is a "timing" too short in Inkscape extensions for an iMac
But how to change this for try ?
comments.author: sv650s

comments.text: We have designed this painting robot mod for the Arduino Leonardo, the Arduino UNO has another different microcontroller and the communication handshake timing is different. We will take a look at it anyway.
comments.author: sv650s

comments.text:
Hi,
i have some news about my problem.
I have put a 10uF between GND and RESET on my arduino uno R3, for card doesn't reset as seen on web.
I have tried on 2 differents computers , one on windows 10, and the second is an iMac 2017
And the result is now ok on my PC windows 10 (no line on egg before start to draw), but not on my iMac.... with this condensator, on my iMac in Inkscape, iMac doesn't want find and connect the arduino card... but if i remove condensator, Inkscape is ok to find and connect on my iMac, but i have again the problem describe in others posts.
Now i would like to know why the 10uF condensator make work well pen up/down on my windows 10 and NOT POSSIBLE to connect on my iMac ?
comments.author: sv650s

comments.text: We have developed the Sphere-o-bot to work with an Arduino Leonardo. It could work with the Arduino UNO but we have not thoroughly checked all the possible incompatibilities. There are some differences on the electronics of both boards (UNO and Leonardo). That capacitor seems to keep the servo output at LOW while initializing the drawing process explaining the problem you are having.
comments.author: sv650s

comments.author: effgee

comments.text:
Hi Effgee!
1) There is a egg holder for the large suction cups (and : (eggsupport[V2]_larger_suction_cups): http://www.thingiverse.com/download:3466219
2) Check the "eggsupport[V2_larger_suction_cups" model, it has a 5,6 mm hole (0,2 mm tolerance for "not so good" 3D printers)
3) Leaving the holder like this (with a bolt to fix it) allows you to centre the egg better. A fitted support will not let you do that easily.
4) The spacer is this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/download:2614479 (Rod_spacer)
5) Check the "egg_support holder SHORT" stl model. Thanks for the feedback! (really)

Ce support pour outils a été conçu spécialement pour la Dagoma Discovery 200.
Les 2 paires d'échancrure permettent de le positionner indifférement sur les rails du chariot de X (lorsque l'imprimante est éteinte, cf. photo 1) ou sur les rails du haut (cf. photo 2), ou toute surface plane bien évidemment.
Il faudra imprimer 2 pieds (ou plus si vos outils sont lourds) et une traverse.
Voici les réglages que j'ai utilisé pour cette impression:

Bloc_Precision label="Qualité (épaisseur de couche) :"
Precision name="Prototype (0.40 mm)"
layer_height=0.4
solid_layer_thickness=0.8
wall_thickness=0.8s
print_speed=5
temp_preci=5
travel_speed=150
bottom_layer_speed=2
infill_speed=80
inset0_speed=50
insetx_speed=60
Remplissage name="5pourcent"
fill_density=5

description.text:
I needed (wanted) a longer handle for this thing so i did it.
Just a quick OpenSCAD that slices the skaft.stl in three pieces (bottom, middle and top) and then, it puts them back together changing the length of the middle section to fit the length that has been entered as a parameter.
I tagged this with the "thing-a-day" tag... Oups! I was too late to sign-up so, I guess I shouldn't. I have no problem to remove the tag :-( just let me know

Just click on "I like it" if it is the case. If you don't like it I will not be upset if you click on "I like it" anyway.
Do not print any of the STL!
Wait until tomorrow for a nice (hopefully) change design.
The handle in the pictures has a length of 90mm (add another 30mm for the thread and you get a 120mm tall print)

comments.text: This is great! I liked the original, I love the derivative. I was unaware of the import command in OpenSCAD. I went back to the online manual (http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/The_OpenSCAD_Languagehttp://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/O... ) and found it wasn't there. Importing other STL's into OpenSCAD really opens up the ability to derive existing designs without crawling through lots of code or even models designed in other file types. Thanks for the lesson.
comments.author: bvesperman

comments.text: Thanks! And thank you very much for the comment!!
comments.author: bvesperman

description.text: This is a case for eToken dual factor authentication tokens. The design protects the LCD screen and prevents the button from being pushed while it is in your pocket. If you place it on the build plate with the open end down, it will print without supports. Photos shown were printed in PLA on a makerbot 2. The design is public and shared within OnShape. This STL is sized for the eToken Pass, but you can easily adjust the size by branching the document in OnShape then editing sketch 1 and adjusting the dimensions.

Time to get our party on! We decided to show our Blue Jays Spirit by laser engraving coconuts with our favourite Toronto Blue Jays pitcher Roberto Osuna on it.

Step 1: Engraving the coconuts

We used the Speedy 300 laser on set on 100 power and 75 speed.

Step 1: Engraving the coconuts Step 1: Engraving the coconuts Step 2: Cracking the coconut

Use this simple technique to open the coconut:

Find the top (pointy side) of the coconut, it should be divided into 3 sections. Take a hammer and smash the top. Do so until it pops off (You can use the milk for whatever you feel like).

Step 2: Cracking the coconut Step 2: Cracking the coconut Step 3: Crush the ice

If you don't have any crushed ice, try taking some ice and wrap it in a towel. Then smash it with a mallet.

Step 3: Crush the ice Step 3: Crush the ice Step 4: The colada!

take 2 ounces of alcohol, coconut milk, tropical medley and agave nectar, shake em up a bit and voilà! Enjoy!

author: ulfd

title: Low Profile Arcade Button Housing Seimitsu PS-15

description.text:
I designed this for my arcade machine to expand the number of buttons from 1 to 6. This is my design to allow the old button to be a cable conduit, and fit this over for 5 more buttons without drilling. I had to modify the button radius to 15.5. If the stl doesn't work for you, just download openscad and change the parameters. The parameters are editable, however, there are present hacks, magic numbers, and Keebler Elves. I uploaded 3 versions, the length is dependant on the pitch, lower the pitch, less claw action causing carpal tunnel, however you might need a smaller one (like I realized I did).
For this I increased the pitch of one, and cut off the palmrest on the other.
You see how this could get you with a reasonably customized product if you wanted to modify the parameters. All of the magic is in the cutoff points so you could comment out that portion and then play with cutting off what you want gone. This was basically my idea to make the machine downgradable, so it can be returned to stock if someone wanted to buy it but didn't want the crazy Raspberry Pi arcade system I installed. To maybe get you more familiar with this silliness, heres my arcade videos.
On youtube: watch?v=ZCf38E1ALG0&list=PLpUQGHNn5fr_xnZhDbku8LxkOC0XMiOvW

comments.text: Dude, this is genius! I may just have to print one up to have if I want to run my Ms Pac Man mame cab temporarily as a street fighter machine.

title: Wanhao i3 X axis microswitch bracket

description.text:
A bracket to drop and "bury" the X axis microswitch, thereby freeing up Z axis space (when drag cable is also moved), physically protecting the switch, and making the top prettier!
This is part of a bigger project to build an all-encompassing case for the entire extruder head which will:

  • be neat;
  • hide all cabling;
  • integrate a cooling system / fan;
  • align the drag cable in the horizontal plane;
  • look nice... :-)

The photos show...

  • Parts required: a spring plus the original microswitch, and M3 bolt;
  • Partial assembly, I used one of the M2 bolts to illustrate how it could be fitted;
  • Sub-assembly, ready to go into printer;

Watch it work here... https://youtu.be/I_ggdAgJ604

PS, vibration will probably cause the plunger to fall out!!! But the case (when designed) will retain it...

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

75%

Notes:

Wanhao Premium Black PLA, setting set for strength as many areas are thin. Supports to help keep round things as round. I'm quite new to this so you may know better...

Finishing off

I cleaned up the plunger with 1,000 wet-and-dry, I don't want it seizing up!
Tap the fat end of the plunger M3.
Tap the narrow end of the plunger M2 (optional).
Use pressure with the existing microswitch M2 screws to "self tap" them into the plate.

Unscrew the drag cable from the extension plate at the top.
Unscrew the extension plate.
Unscrew top bearing bolts.
Attach on end of the plate, slide extruder frame under it, align next bearing.
Do up all the M4 bolts (I used black, flanged M4s because they look nice).

Mount, tightening the bolts slowly so as not to twist the bearings, causing tight movement.
Adjust the M3 bolt to get the frame clearance you want.

More to come

On its own this isn't enough, you now have nowhere to mount the drag cable!!
So watch this space...

The SCAD code is 100% basic, nothing clever.
